channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Letter From Washington: A New Ethos Grips North Carolina
item.description: As Republicans took full control of the state, there has been a shift to the right. Taxes for the wealthy have been slashed, and spending for education and programs that benefit the poor has been cut.
item.dc:creator: By ALBERT R. HUNT | BLOOMBERG VIEW

item.title: Morsi Supporters Vow to Defy Egypt’s Military
item.description: Supporters of the ousted president, Mohamed Morsi, and backers of the military prepared to test each side’s resolve as the Islamists announced another series of marches and rallies.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Chinese Politician to Stand Trial on Corruption Charges
item.description: Bo Xilai, an ambitious politician whose downfall shook the Communist Party elite, will face charges of bribery, corruption and abuse of power.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: 2 Koreas Agree to Discuss Reunions for Families
item.description: Revival of a humanitarian program would be another step toward a thaw on the divided Korean Peninsula after months of tension.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Sotheby’s to Auction Rare Diamond in Hong Kong
item.description: The 7.59-carat, blue-colored stone is expected to bring about $19 million.
item.dc:creator: By BETTINA WASSENER

item.title: Mexico Captures a Cartel Leader
item.description: A military operation near the Texas border netted Mario Armando Ramirez Treviño, a leader of the drug-trafficking Gulf Cartel.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: In Little Egypt, Echoes From Home
item.description: Egyptians in New York are following the news from back home with great anxiety, and here, as in Egypt, they disagree about the causes of the bloody conflict.

item.title: Vietnam Reduces Dissidents’ Terms
item.description: An appeals court overturned one dissident’s six-year prison sentence and halved the term of another in a rare show of leniency.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Report Shows Modest Rise in Requests for Asylum
item.description: Requests along the border with Mexico have more than doubled over the last three years as immigrants claim a fear of persecution back home, a federal government report found.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: DealBook: Hiring in China By JPMorgan Under Scrutiny
item.description: Authorities have opened a bribery investigation into whether JPMorgan Chase hired the children of powerful Chinese officials to help the bank win lucrative business in the booming nation.
item.dc:creator: By JESSICA SILVER-GREENBERG, BEN PROTESS and DAVID BARBOZA
item.media:description: Tang Shuangning, the chairman of the China Everbright Group.

item.title: Soldiers Storm a Mosque in Cairo, as Egyptian Leaders Struggle for Order
item.description: A standoff between supporters of the ousted president, Mohamed Morsi, and soldiers at a mosque ended with no reports of casualties, but it was emblematic of Egypt’s wider chaos.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and MAYY EL SHEIKH
item.media:description: An army officer pointed his weapon at the crowd as he helped a man to leave Cairo's Fateh Mosque on Saturday.

item.title: Radio Station Employee Is Shot Dead in Somalia
item.description: A technician for the state-run broadcaster Radio Mogadishu was killed by two armed men outside his home on Saturday, and another man was executed for killing a journalist last year.
item.dc:creator: By MOHAMMED IBRAHIM and NICHOLAS KULISH

item.title: Sectarian Attacks Return With a Roar to Iraq, Rattling a Capital Already on Edge
item.description: The drastic surge in violence from car bombs and security sweeps has a lent a new sense of Balkanization to Baghdad.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO
item.media:description: The aftermath of a car-bomb attack in the Shiite stronghold of Sadr City in Baghdad last month.

item.title: How American Hopes for a Deal in Egypt Were Undercut
item.description: Egypt’s military crackdown has left President Obama in a no-win position: risk a partnership that has been the bedrock of Middle East peace, or stand by while allies try to hold on to power by mowing down opponents.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK, PETER BAKER and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Soldiers reacted to gunfire on Saturday in a mosque where backers of the ousted president had taken refuge.

item.title: The Lede: Latest Updates on Crackdown in Egypt
item.description: The Lede is following events in Egypt on Saturday, where Islamist protesters have taken to the streets again to demonstrate against the military-backed government that killed hundreds this week.
item.dc:creator: By LIAM STACK
item.media:description: Mostafa Hegazi, a political adviser and spokesman for Egypt’s interim president, Adli Mansour, spoke at the presidential palace in Cairo on Saturday.

item.title: A Secret Race for Abandoned Nuclear Material
item.description: Over a period of 17 years, Russian and American scientists collaborated to remove hundreds of pounds of plutonium and highly enriched uranium from a nuclear test site in Kazakhstan.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY
item.media:description: Soldiers near the center of the former Soviet nuclear test site in Semipalatinsk, Kazakhstan.

item.title: Jamaica Fights to Break Grip of Violent Past
item.description: The island nation is emerging as a bright spot in the fight against drugs and organized crime that extends across the region.
item.dc:creator: By DAMIEN CAVE
item.media:credit: Andrea Bruce for The New York Times
item.media:description: Girls leaving school for home in the Mountain View neighborhood in Kingston, which used to be notorious for its crime but has become safer, thanks in part to community policing.

item.title: The Lede: Aug. 16 Updates on Protests in Egypt
item.description: The Lede is following events in Egypt on Friday, where Islamist protesters have taken to the streets to demonstrate against the military-backed government.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Prominent Advocate Held in Southern China
item.description: Yang Maodong, better known by his pen name, Guo Feixiong, is the second well-known member of China’s “rights defense” movement to be arrested in recent weeks.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Blood and Chaos Prevail in Egypt, Testing Control
item.description: Egypt erupted into chaos on Friday, raising doubts about the authorities’ capacity to maintain order, as opponents of the military takeover fought security forces and civilians in the street.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: A supporter of the ousted president, Mohamed Morsi, prayed as a wounded friend was treated in Ramses Square in Cairo.

item.title: Layoffs Taboo, Japan Workers Are Sent to the Boredom Room
item.description: Facing a sluggish economy and increasing competition, Japan’s prime minister and major companies want to reduce longstanding restrictions on dismissing full-time workers.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI
item.media:credit: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times
item.media:description: Miwako Sato joined Sony right out of high school in 1974.

item.title: Political Memo: Attacks on Protesters in Cairo Were Calculated to Provoke, Some Say
item.description: The ferocity of the attacks appears to have been a deliberate calculation of the military-appointed government to provoke violence from the Muslim Brotherhood and its allies, historians said Friday.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Egyptian military guarding the remains of the Rabaa al-Adawiya mosque in Cairo, near which Islamist supporters of Mohamed Morsi had staged their protest.

item.title: Business Briefing | Legal News: Swiss Lawyer Pleads Guilty to Conspiracy in Tax Fraud
item.description: A Swiss lawyer accused of helping American clients conceal millions of dollars in offshore accounts pleaded guilty to conspiracy to commit tax fraud in federal court in New York.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Thrust Into Nonstop Turmoil, an Obama Adviser Counsels Pragmatism
item.description: Susan E. Rice, in her six weeks as national security adviser, has dealt with a terrorist scare, deteriorating relations with Russia and, now, the chaos in Egypt.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: Susan E. Rice, left, seen in the White House Rose Garden in June, has been on the job as national security adviser for six weeks.

item.title: Hezbollah Makes Vow to Step Up Sunni Fight
item.description: Hasan Nasrallah, the leader of Hezbollah, accused radical Sunnis of orchestrating a car bombing that killed 24 in Beirut.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD
item.media:description: Shiite Muslims gathered Friday for a televised speech by Hasan Nasrallah, Hezbollah's leader.
